citeinfo.origin: Webster, M. S., P. P. Mara, S. M. Haig, S. Bensch, and R. T. Holmes
citeinfo.title: Links between worlds: Unraveling migratory connectivity
citeinfo.othercit: Science Information System Project #: 7042 Publication Control #: 1072

descript.abstract: Migration is the movement of individuals that occurs seasonally each year, and often entails traveling from a breeding location to a nonbreeding location and back again. Migration is a widespread phenomenon in nature, and is particularly common among birds. The extent to which individuals from the same breeding area migrate to the same nonbreeding area (termed migratory connectivity), and vice versa, is a very important and yet unresolved issue in the study of migratory birds. This paper discusses new technologies for better understanding the ecology and evolution of migrating organisms. New advances in satellite telemetry, genetic analyses, and stable isotope chemistry are discussed as pertinent tools for determining the population and geographical origin of individual birds. In this paper, the advantages and limitations to these new approaches are considered the link between migratory connectivity to other ecological, evolutionary, and conservation issues.
